c74object.name: SDIF-fileinfo
c74object.digest: Report information about the streams in an SDIF file
c74object.description: SDIF-fileinfo scans a file on disk and reports useful info out its outlets. These data are different depending on the file accessed.

objarg.name: buffer name
objarg.description: The name of the SDIF-buffer. Required because it has to be referenced by other objects in the SDIF suite. The name of an SDIF-buffer is like the name of an MSP buffer~: it's a symbol that you assign as an argument to the SDIF-buffer object, and then other objects refer to the SDIF-buffer by its name.

method.name: bang
method.description: Outputs filename, number of streams, and stream info in OSC-style messages.

method.name: clear
method.description: Forget about the most recently scanned file.

method.name: scan
method.description: Read through all frame headers in an SDIF file to get info about the streams in the file. If the object sees a name/value table (a 1NVT matrix in a 1NVT frame), it prints the contents to the Max window. The file must be in Max's search path for this message to function.

method.name: version
method.description: Print version information to the Max window.

entry.name: Inlet 1 [anything]
entry.description: Send a message to the sdif-fileinfo object.

entry.name: Outlet 1 [list]
entry.description: sdif-fileinfo outputs osc-style messages if a valid file has been scanned successfully.

entry.name: Outlet 2 [list]
entry.description: output osc-style messages if a valid 1NVT header has been found. See helpfile for an example on how to populate a UI object with these data.

entry.name: More details
entry.description: An SDIF stream is a matrix of data that can be queried, manipulated, and written. The Sound Description Interchange Format (“SDIF”) offers a framework for representing high-level sound descriptions such as sum-of-sinusoids, noise bands, time-domain samples, and formants. Many of these sound descriptions are mutable models, affording operations such as filtering, morphing, pitch shifting, and time stretching. SDIF data consists of time-tagged frames, each containing one or more two-dimensional matrices of data such as floating-point numbers and a frame type ID indicating what kind of sound description the frame represents. For example, an SDIF frame representing additive synthesis data has a single matrix where rows represent individual sinusoids and columns represent parameters such as frequency, amplitude, and phase. A stream is a sequence of frames of the same frame type that represents a single “sonic object” evolving through time. An SDIF file may contain one stream, or multiple streams with interleaved frames. Each frame has a Stream ID, a meaningless 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the stream to which it belongs.
